instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: So I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not powering on. It was working, just had a couple corroded capacitor ends so I touched them up and UC'd the board. It now draws 0A @ 20V, but had PP#V# and PPBUS is 13.1V. Not sure what the heck is going on. Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
Why the people like so much to pass a board through UC?
To clean few caps, use toothbrush!

Now you can have knocked off components, or broken traces.
Did you use sweep function at least?
Did you dry the board correctly?

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: yes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: Seem to be missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> an <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> either

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: I've got ONE reply for 3 questions; what should I understand???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
you actually asked 4 questions.

Answer  1. Because there was flux that may have gone under <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> because the cap I replaced was right above it.

Answer 2. Yes I used the sweep function

Answer 3. I dried for 1 hour

Answer 4. I was getting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. When I search for SUS I don’t see anything for that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
You cannot get S4 voltages, nor signals, if missing <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
This imply missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and you have to find why PCH pulls down that signal.
Start checking PCH's RTC signals and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> at page 60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - .398V

<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - .398V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - .398V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - .398V
<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PSH</SIGNAL> - .340V

threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 2.8V

<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.08V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.08V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.08V
<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PSH</SIGNAL> - 1.1V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> I have 500 Ohms to GND.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> must be high, if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: ok, yeah it is present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: Does 530 Ohms on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> seem low? I don't have another board for reference, besides an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is a donor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
00840/75 are almost the same.
You should compare diode mode readings (red probe at ground), not ohm scale.

"and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> at page 60."
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: I'm not sure which signals are important

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
Start with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10).
Also check <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> (10 OF 10) at page 61.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: Ok, so all of the outputs seem to be there, <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> IS 3.1 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL>?

Check all resistors around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
You may need to reball it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> = 3.28V
I will check resistors and if they are all good, will reball PMIC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: Then you MUST have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: Reballed PMIC and no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: You didn't comment about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: It is present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
I supposed both signals, as <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> too, are high already.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: I'm looking at this board again. I found R 7062 is 263 Ohms. I replaced it and board went to 20 @ .02 amps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not powering on after UC
threads.message: Which voltages present from power on sequence?
